title: The Protégé OWL Plugin: An Open Development Environment for Semantic Web Applications

author: Mark A. Musen, School of Medicine, Stanford University

segmentation: Thanks Audie thanks.
Thank all of you.
This is really a wonderful and amazing experience.
I'm really exhilarated.

I wasn't sure how would be how exhilarated I would feel knowing I was getting an award with my coauthors for work that was done 10 years ago I. I know that when I reached a point in my career when I was no longer eligible for Young Investigator awards I got, I got very depressed.
Get out now that it's been 10 years is really quite remarkable.
10 years seems like a long time on the slide.
You see the logo that we used to use for the Protege project 10 years ago.
Many people in this room I know want us to bring this logo back, but.
I. I will not get into that conversation right now.
I really want to thank all of my Co authors who works really hard on this on this project, and I obviously want to thank the Committee and Switzer for choosing us.
This is an unusual paper for eswick.
This is a paper that talked about a piece of software.
It didn't even talk about a piece of software that we had really evaluated all that well.
It mainly was an opportunity to build into an existing ontology editing tool.
The capability of dealing with owl and that experience obviously helped us enormously in our own work internally, and obviously has some effects on that.
Community, all of the folks you see on the author list contributed extensively to the paper Annie's Lucy, except for Holger, who I'm told is on the beach in Queensland.

Everyone else is here, and I'm really grateful that my coauthors could could could be here to share this moment, but I think I will really want to emphasize was unusual, but Protege is the fact that this project has been going on so long.

And in fact, Lossed in the list of all the people who worked on this project over the past 25 years or so are my coauthors, as well as lots of other people have made stellar contributions to the software, many of whom are actually in this room in other capacities now.
And for those of you who will look at these slides on the web later, you can, you can play the where are they now game?
Because some of the folks have worked on the sponsor protege work have been just absolutely wonderful colleagues and collaborators.
And I should mention, these are the folks who have been funded by grants that have supported Prodigy over the years.
There are also hundreds of people who have contributed plugins, other kinds of additions to the software, and I don't want to diminish their contributions either.
So the time that we submitted this paper, this was the meeting in 2004 in Hiroshima World was actually a somewhat different place than it is now.
The language wars that some of you may remember from about 1015 years ago had receded an owl one.
There were other contenders.
We will not discuss those other contenders.
I will not revisit that debate either, but ALS certainly had the recommendation of W3C and we knew that there were lots of other folks are doing.
Really good work and developing ontology editors to support description logics.
Folks like Manchester and Maryland, and we can obviously learn a lot from them.
This is also at a time when the semantic web was really still being talked about in terms of intelligence distributed across the Internet.
The linked data community was just bubbling up at this time, but unlike the current conference and the and, the word was that Carol showed a moment ago.
Really, this was a meeting about intelligent systems on the web and the importance of ontologies in building those systems and semantic web really was at its trendy as if you.
Google Trend semantic web.
You'll see 2004 was really the peak at which people were searching for that particular phrase.
It was also kind of a strange time because our working protege was not specifically the building ontology.
We wanted to build an interactive development environment environment for creating intelligent systems and to do that we knew we needed lots of abstractions.
Everett, much more useful than the usual shells that were being used for expert systems of that era.
We wanted to be able to have components like ontologies and problem solvers that we could edit and bring together, and that was really the purpose of Protege.
We saw ontologies as being a small part of that.
If you vote for those of you from the United States will be familiar with the with the commercial that talks about cereal.
Being only part of a complete breakfast and we viewed ontologies only a small part of what we were doing.
But obviously the significance of that group considered.
Over the years, so for an astrologist sake, here's what Protege looked like circa 1992.
In next step you can see the protege nerd in the upper left hand side of the screen, serving up in an ontology using the next step browser.
Got some great funding from DARPA and the United States.
We said what the hell you doing playing around in next step?
You know where the world is going?
So he gave us lots of money to move everything over to Windows.
That lasted a little while, and then as you all know, we've moved.
Over to a plug in architecture in Java and this, this slide shows a very early version of the Java version of Protege here with the NCI Thesaurus as being the content that's being displayed.
And now as many of you might know.
A lot of our attention is focusing on the web itself, where Protege which Natasha isn't working on extensively.

Tonya to Rocky and other members of my group spent a lot of time working on over the past two or three years gives us a new way of looking at ontologies on the web in ways which I think are are just absolutely spectacular and the work that we've done in creating this foundation has really allowed us to experiment with new ways of ontology engineering, which I think are valuable.
Certainly the projects at Stanford and hopefully to those of our community who used.
So per ziaul when we presented this for 10 years ago, want us lots of friends.
Al was the new de facto standard and we suddenly had an editor that was good for it.
Or so we thought it was open and had a plug in architecture and so everybody could tell us what we had done wrong and create new plugins to fix things up in ways they thought were better.

And it really helped us build a strong community behind this software and I think it was very important for us was not just the ability to present a piece of software at this meeting, but to actually use that as an opportunity to gather.
Colleagues who contribute to the codebase and make protege.
I think what it is now.

And it really started if you will, then this virtuous cycle of people using Protege to build systems to use, Protege to experiment, and I think the infrastructure that we started with Protege Owl has led not not only to more infrastructure but also to more science.
And I think that relationship is really very important.
Lots of headaches too.
People love al or do not love Al.

We don't want to get into the language wars again, but I think one of the issues that we deal with in our particular group are the cadre of users who are actually looking for ontology editors and ontology languages that are far simpler and far less expressive, and I think that's one of the issues that our community continues to grapple with.
We didn't know this in 2004, but actually layering an editor for Owl on top of an existing frame editor.
Was it really expedient thing to do?
But architecturally was not a great thing to do, and it took us awhile to understand why we had to backtrack and why we had to rethink that.
A lot of the decisions we had made in software engineering.
And fundamentally, we learned that we really had no business doing this work in the 1st place.
It really is a dumb idea for academic groups to be building software that so many people rely on, particularly when we're supported only by soft money.

But we thought we had to do it anyway, 'cause we really didn't see the commercial world providing the kinds of capabilities and the new features that we thought were very important for experimental work in the semantic web.
And so we persisted anyway.
So what have we learned after 10 years?

Well, I think we've learned that infrastructure is really important to science in this community, but that infrastructure is really underrated that people don't realize how hard it is sometimes to build the kinds of foundations that we used to do, the experiments that are really so important to us and sometimes not all the times.

But sometimes academic groups really are the ones who have to build that infrastructure because only we who are in the academic community can really understand the science that academics want to watch it.
Pursue those of us in industry and government often will follow and often will follow with much better designs 'cause they build software better than we do.
But sometimes those initial ideas need to come from the people who are closest to the scientific problems.
I think funding agencies need to put much more emphasis on infrastructure because they assume that everything is going to come from commercial sources and often that is the case.
But particularly in the systems such as Protege, that simply was never going to happen and I think the more that we can convince our funders that there's a real.
The real value in supporting the infrastructure on which I work depends though the better off we all will be.
And frankly, we learned that scientific communities such as this one really make all this hassle worth it.

That we get a lot of excitement not only about using Protege in our own work to investigate new opportunities and knowledge engineering, and to study new ways of knowledge engineering, but the way in which we interact with our community, the way our Inter community gives us new ideas that we can incorporate in our work has just been enormously gratifying.
And so I think one of the things that I want to leave with you with is not.
Only has this been a great 10 years for the Protege project, but it's been a great 10 years.
Not just because of the paper we've submitted in 2004, but because of the interactions we've had with the entire semantic web community in the interim.
And so with that, let me again, thank Harvey and thank the the Committee.
But most importantly, thank all of you.
